title: Global Stocks Rallied Friday on Trade Optimism
text:
PSG Wealth Daily Investment Update, 14 October 2019

The JSE rose on Friday, as global markets climbed on the news that talks between the US and China over their trade impasse were progressing well. The JSE rose 0.84%.Wall Street opened higher on Friday, with high hopes that talks between President Donald Trump and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He would culminate in a partial trade deal. Shortly after the JSE’s closed the was up by 1.59%.Reports on Friday that UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his Irish counterpart found a pathway to a possible Brexit deal after three years of uncertainty boosted markets. Just after the JSE closed, the had gained 0.65%, France’s 1.47%, and Germany’s 2.46%.Shares in China and Hong Kong jumped on Friday, as investors cheered signs of progress in the ongoing Sino-US trade talks. The added 2.34%.Japanese shares rose on Friday as the safe-haven yen eased on hopes of progress in US-China trade talks. The ended up 1.15%.The rand broke through the R15/$ level on Friday on hope that the US and China could make progress in trade negotiations. At 17h35 the rand traded more than 2% firmer at R14.74/$.Gold prices fell on Friday, as optimism around the US-China trade talks and the possibility of a Brexit deal diminished safe-haven interest in bullion. At 20h00 an ounce of traded at $1 484.78.Oil prices jumped on Friday after Iranian media said a state-owned oil tanker had been struck by missiles in the Red Sea near Saudi Arabia, raising the prospect of supply disruptions weeks after attacks on Saudi oil plants. A barrel of traded at $60.58 at 20h00.
